message: So, you have some random text from a web page, and you want to auto-tag it, extract keywords, etc., what else can you use other than using meta tag keywords?

data.message: * assuming you do not have a pre-defined set of tags to test the text against
Regex can be used to extract text like phones, zip code, dates... etc

Also you can use some machine learning techniques for classification. 
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13788229/very-simple-text-classification-by-machine-learning
What I'm after is exacting keywords rather than meta information. Say you want to display tags in this group's archive and want it to apply to historical posts which don't have explicit #tags.
I think that you mean part-of-speech tagging. This is an example by Tarek Amr https://github.com/gr33ndata/NLP_GDGCairo2013

Like Google and other SE, I would depend first on then header tags, then <strong> / <b> , first paragraph <p>, then the last part of the URL (page name), then the keywords and description meta tags, then the rest of copy on page and <img>'s alternate text, it requires some NLP to get good results
Great stuff Mohammad Tayseer. Dies the idea change much if my target is extracting list of tags (to display to user all the tags from all recorded pages) rather than testing for predefined list?
Is it Named-entity recognition what you need, or what? Give me an example of what you consider "keywords" here? http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Named-entity_recognition

Let's say you want add tags to previous posts in the group archive, like JavaScript, AngularJS, CSS, etc. Let's ignore that AngularJS is JavaScript, you want to tag the posts, and get lost if distinct tags to display to use, preferably without stating from a predefined list (or some technique to obtain large list, and allow fast testing of all tags in this list)
If you have a predefined list of tags, then it is text classification, if no predefined list of tags then it is text clustering.

I do think that the solutions suggested so far are overkill (giddan giddan). If all you need is to extract a few good tags for each post then I would suggest that you either do some clustering, or simply calculate co-occurence (how often 2 words appear together in the same sentence/paragraph/post versus how often those words appear in general). To make things a little more useful I suggest that you exclude all stop words (like a, the, that, etc. example here http://www.textfixer.com/resources/common-english-words.txt), and if you want to get fancy, calculate tf-idf scores for each co-occurence to narrow down the really useful stuff (but now we're back in overkill territory :D ). Hope that helps. ;)

I don't want to get fancy, I wouldn't mind a service that does this for me or some software to install and interop with somehow :D
It's something I might give up for now though.
